flowRoot.flowPara: Code is written and run as normal, but with parameters and subdomain IDs provided by Go-Smart Python modules. These, in turn, read parameters from local YAML files.

text.tspan: A Tool To Separate Web-user, Manufacturer and Researcher Concerns Through Extensible Simulation Containerization

flowRoot.flowPara: Glossia is an open source tool to manage simulation execution, locally or in the cloud.
Simulations can be run offline or remotely and easily switched between the two, with near-identical environments.

To achieve this, Glossia abstracts external parameters such as case-specific input, to help de-couple code from settings in a way that is reproducible whether on a laptop, on a remote computational machine or on a web platform.

While Glossia provides support for uploading executable configuration, the actual numerical codes are made available to end users by white-listing numerical tools. These are wrapped in Docker containers, using a basic Python API to interact with Glossia - these containers are referred to as "families" and containers for new numerical tools may be built quickly from existing templates. Glossia's AGPL license does not affect the licensing of codes within containers.

Open source families are available for FEniCS and Elmer. An industry project has also tested OpenFOAM. FEniCS is recommended, as it provides direct Python bindings, allowing interaction between orchestration and simulation modules. Elmer models are defined as an Elmer SIF, enhanced with Jinja2 templating.

Using an optional template base container, the Glossia tool allows a set of regions to be defined externally (e.g. via a segmentation tool), automatically volumetrically meshed and referenced within the simulation code semantically. At present, in-progress feedback is via status updates, with expansion subject to security considerations.

text.tspan: Simulations may be easily switched between four levels of configuration.

flowRoot.flowPara: The same code is run in the Docker container that will be used in deployment. The same parameters are used as in the previous step. Glossia is not run.

Glossia is run on the local machine or local network. A command line utility, glot, facilitates job submission, monitoring and (on local machine) direct retrieval of results or debugging output. Alternatively, Glossia can push results to a file server.

Online service. Parameters may be set through the platform, linked with other components built by users of the platform (e.g. medical equipment profiles). The Python code bundle is uploaded to the server.

The system is designed to maximize environment p;arity between steps 2, 3 and 4. Image IDs of Glossia-FEniCS sandbox containers are contained within debug output and used to re-run simulations in an identical container locally as remotely.
Command line scripts manage execution at each stage, and glot has built in commands to simplify transition.
To allow interdependent components to be built into a single simulatable parameter set, a framework relating them is required.
Each component supplies named parameters, some of which may be given by clinicians at simulation-time, some by researchers when defining the component.
For each modality, that is, physically similar set of treatments, many models of needle and power generator exist.

The Clinical Domain Model (CDM) is largely independent of Glossia, and is not essential to use Glossia, but the XML input format for Glossia reflects the numerical model, parameter, needle separation - only as a pair is the flexibility in Go-Smart achievable.
Algorithms allow simulation parameters to be defined as simple functions of transient simulation variables, "Arguments", (perhaps independently of the numerical model developer).
E: Clinical Domain Model relationships. This shows the relationships in defining a simulatable Combination of components.
The lines indicate links of components to each other (black) and, one-to-many, with parameters (green). The primary components are ringed in black and joined to the Combination with red lines.
F: Components and their parameter values must be considered separately in the abstract (Abstract) , when a real-world case has been chosen (Case) and once a simulation has been defined (Simulation).

Technical summary: Glossia is managed via a WAMP router (e.g. Crossbar.io) allowing clients to be language independent and run remotely. WAMP is a WebSocket subprotocol. Interaction is via RPC and PubSub patterns. Simulation definition is in an XML format. Region definition is usually in STL or STEP format.
This project has built a platform to help clinicians, researchers and product manufacturers interact online, primarily within the field of Minimally Invasive Cancer Treatments (MICTs).
Clinicians use the platform in, e.g., clinical trials to upload patient data, manage it and perform intervention simulations.
They segment data (B), run simulations (C) and may share datasets or perform validation on results.
Researchers may add numerical models to the platform & manufacturers add new equipment (D) or clinical protocols.
Parameter values may be made adjustable by users at simulation-time, or predefined. Researchers may reuse existing numerical models and equipment to create new simulatable combinations.

Illustration of Simulation Families: upper is generic, new containers can be created without using any Glossia tools or libraries. A specific example is shown below, the Glossia-FEniCS container. Any Glossia tools intended for use inside the container are licensed to remain compatible with both open or closed licensing of in-container code and user code. In addition, user STL files and parameters are injected into the container by Glossia.
